title: Auction vs Direct Purchase vs Consignment
metaTitle: Auction vs Direct Sale vs Consignment | Wine Selling Options | Proof Cellars
metaDescription: Deep dive into the three main ways to sell wine. Understand the fee structures, risks, and timelines of Auctions vs Direct Buyers.
summary: How to choose a path based on speed, certainty, and the types of bottles you have.

sections.heading: Quick Answer
list: Auction: High Risk / High Reward / Slow.
Direct Purchase: Zero Risk / Fixed Reward / Fast.
Consignment: Medium Risk / Medium Reward / Slow.

sections.heading: Detailed Breakdown: Auctions
content: Auctions are theater. They rely on two bidders getting into a fight to drive up price.
list: Buyer's Premium: The buyer pays ~25% on top of the hammer price. This limits what they bid.
Seller's Commission: You pay ~15% to 0% depending on value.
Listing Fees: Insurance, photography, cataloging fees add up.
Timeline: Submission -> Catalog (1 month) -> Auction (1 month) -> Collection (1 month) -> Payout (1 month).

sections.heading: Detailed Breakdown: Direct Purchase
content: A simple transaction. We agree on a number, we pay, we take it.
list: Fees: None (net to you).
Timeline: Submission -> Quote (2 days) -> Payment -> Pickup (1 week).
Certainty: 100%. No 'unsold' lots.

sections.heading: Detailed Breakdown: Consignment
content: You place wine in a retailer's shop. When it sells, you get paid.
list: Split: Typically 75/25 or 80/20 (You get the larger share).
Control: You often set the price.
Speed: Glacial. It sells when a customer walks in and wants it.

sections.heading: Hidden Fees Checklist
list: Insurance Fee (usually 1%).
Pickup/Logistics Fee.
Buy-back Fee (cost to get your own wine back if it doesn't sell).
Photography Fee.

sections.heading: What to Do Next
list: Is it a $10,000 bottle? Maybe try auction.
Is it a $200 bottle? Direct sale is far more efficient.
Get a Direct Offer from us first to set a baseline.

faqs.question: Why do auctions take so long?
faqs.answer: They usually run quarterly or monthly schedules and need time to print catalogs and market the sale.

faqs.question: Can I set a reserve price?
faqs.answer: Yes, but if the reserve isn't met, the wine doesn't sell and you often still pay fees.

faqs.question: Do you offer consignment?
faqs.answer: Sometimes, for exceptional collections where the seller wants to wait for a specific price.

faqs.question: Is direct sale fairer?
faqs.answer: It is more transparent. You know exactly what you get.
